Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:To locate a choker not located in a jewelry box or boutique where would you go? Choices:  A: jewelry store B: neck C: jewlery box D: jewelry box E: boutique<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:Use the following statement.<n><n>### 1. Input: The sum of the ages of my nephews is 45 years old. If the sum of the ages of their sons is 14, then how much older is their father than the oldest nephew?<n><n>### 2. Input:The average temperature of the room is 75 degrees Fahrenheit and the average temperature of the room with the window open is 80 degrees Fahrenheit. If the room had an air conditioner, what would the average temperature be?<n><n>### Response 1:Input:  The sum of the ages  of my nephews  is 45 years  old. If the sum  of the ages of their  sons is 14 years  old, then how much older  is their father than the  oldest nephew?<n>Response:Their father is 69 years old<n><n>### Response2:Input:  The average temperature of the room  is 75 degrees  Fahrenheit and the  average temperature of the room   with the window open  is 80 degrees  Fahrenheit. If  the room had air conditioner, what  would the average temperature be ?<n>Response:65.25<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Input2: The ages of the 3 people  at the party add up to 47  years old. If  the youngest of those  people is 16, how  old is the oldest?<n><n>### Instuction:<n>### Input:The oldest among the guests  at the party was 48 years old.<n>###Response:<n>###48<n><n>### Input

What was the location of she was headed?<n><n>Answer:<n>B: military<n><n>### Input The couple have been together for five years. Every month for the first year they spent $100 in dinning. Next year they spent $200. Then each year they spent $150 more than the previous year. After five years they spent $800 per month. What was the monthly expense for their first month together?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: The couple has been together for five(5) years. Every month for year 1 they spent $102.73 in dinning, next year they spent $315.08, then each year they spent $272.95 more than they spent the year before. After five years they spend $840.00 per month in dining.<n><n>The question asked how much was spent in dinning in the first month.<n><n>### Input  A family plans to travel to the following cities during their cross-country trip: Portland, San Francisco, Washington DC, Boston, and Miami. Do you think any of them is reasonable? If you choose something, explain it fully.<n><n>1. Yes, trees can hear. If the tree falls with a loud sound, other trees would hear it for miles around.<n><n>2. The forest is a complete eco system. Just like a human is an eco system. If a person is injured at home, then someone would still hear it.<n><n>3. Yes, it does.<n><n>4. The forest is a large area. Who ever falls within the range of the sound, hear it.<n><n>5. Hurley is 9 years younger than Richard. Their total<n>## age 9 years from now is 66.<n><n>print ("Hurley is younger than Richard")<n><n>## Answer <n>## Ages of the people are different<n>## Richard is younger than Hurley<n>## Printing the total ages in which the people would be 9 years from now.<n><n>print( 66)<n>```<n><n>## Input: Pablo’s mother agreed to pay him one cent<n>## for every page he read. What mark will the students receive at the exam (if she gives a mark of more than 100%?) What percentage of marks does the teacher give to students?<n><n>### Response<n><n>> The teacher gets 90 points for the 100% that are given to everybody. Now she gives a plus 5 extra to the students; then this marks 95, and this 95 is a percentage of 50%. The students who take the exam receive 3 x 95 which is 285. There is a 100%, a 95%, and a 50% of all the students; this 100% is given to everybody and a 95% is given to every one of the students then a 50% is given to many students but in the end, the student can't receive more than a 100%.<n>

She also said that that I can feel satisfied if I get good grades next semester. I don't want my mom to be sad if I don't have good grades, therefore, I have to study hard and get good grades.

This means Pablo has a specific amount of pages in mind when he decides to read a book. The question is _________? Answer: A B<n><n>**Q3.** Pablo spent $8.5 on books and $4.5 on candy. Each book is “exactly 100” pages. That means for every 100 pages that Pablo reads, he gets $1.50 back. What is the amount leftover after Pablo saved all his money? Answer: A B

If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What would children do if they are bored? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:In what place could you find air that has been breathed by only a few people recently? Choices:  A: train station B: house C: cupboard D: cricket stadium E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		 In the answer: B : house, air has not been breathed by more people recently than in any of the other places.<n><n>We can assume that in place A, at least a few times a lot of people must have breathed the air at the train station, as well a lot of people breathe in air at B. Then C, D, and E are less probable options.<n><n>### Input/Explanation:<n><n>I tried to write answer "B" but mark of wrong, what is wrong? The explanation is also confusing:<n>1. Why A is incorrect? Why "more people" cannot be a few?<n><n>2. I can't figure out what does "few" mean here. If I take 5 people, is it few? or many?<n><n>Thanks for the help.<n><n>Comment: _"few times a lot of people"_ does not make any sense. Did you perhaps mean "a few times many people" (i.e. the train station)?<n><n>Comment: @DarthFennec I think I got it right. I used the word "lots of people" (in my response) and that word I thought was similar to few which made no sense, or they are not interchangeable. I mean here: *At least a few times, many people must have breathed at the train station*<n><n>Comment: Ok. Then I understand that you interpreted "more recently" to mean something like "less than X or less often than X". Maybe an explanation like "a fraction of all air in train station B" would be clearer.<n><n>Comment: @LearnAhead yes, I think "fraction of all air in the train station" sounds better.<n><n>Answer: Let's go by the example<n><n>\begin{blockquote}<n><n>The chef has 60 \strong{eggs}....<n>\end{blockquote}<n><n>To make that clear, we have to decide \strong{that in the question the chef has less than 100} eggs. That being the case, it doesn't follow that he has "many" eggs in train stations, nor that he has more eggs in the cupboard.<n><n>Likewise with cricket stadiums. He could have many people coming in and out there, but that would not make that a "place where only a few" have "recently"

Answer them in your own words. Then I just had to start looking.<n><n>### Name three numbers between 6 and 20 whose next number comes after them and before them.<n><n>### Answer<n>6, 7, and 9<n><n>6's next number is 7, and then 7's next number is a 9.  <n>6, 7 and 9 are all numbers between 5 and 20.<n><n>### Is 9 larger than 5? Yes or No?<n><n>### Answers <n>No<n><n>### Why? Yes or Now? I am not sure if I did this correct, but I used your process of subtracting to get 4, and then I said that 9 is smaller (1-4 is 9, and 5-4 is 1, so in comparison, 9 < 1)

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What does a virus primarily do to a person? The task will be in question format. An output will be provided, but only the output is relevant to what you need to do. Your job is to figure out what input went into the process to produce the output.<n><n>The way you know you have answered the question correctly is by selecting the output. Please answer clearly (to both me and your fellow students) so that everyone’s answers are clear!<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The other passengers on the bus were quite loud, so he put on his headphones to relax and what? Choices:  A: go to bed B: sleep C: listen to music D: stretch out E: stop worrying<n><n>### Response:		 C<n><n>| Scene | Speaker                                            | Answer                                 |<n>| ----- | -----------------------------------------------    | --------------------------------------  |<n>| Act 1 | [Carl](https://github.com/CodingQuestions/April-Questions/blob/main/day2.md#carl) and his passengers | A                                                                                    |<n>| Act 2 | [Carl](http://www.codingame.com/play/457550#!/home) and his passengers                      | C\D                                                                              |<n>| Act 3 | [The Passengers](http://www.duysh.com/4851/48471-122008) and the one-eyed man behind them | B                                                                                  |<n>

Richard is 19 and Hurley is 13. How old are they 42 years from now?<n>- **Answer:** 73<n><n>### Demand:<n>Pablo’s mother agreed to pay him one cent per page he read. He plans to save money to buy some candy. Pablo reads books that are exactly 250 pages. After he read his book, he went to the candy store and bought enough candy for $23 + 47 cents. How many books did he read?<n>- **Answer**: 22<n><n>### Demander:<n>A group of people planned to buy a car, the cost of the car is ​​$3000, and they split the cost equally. They hold a car wash to raise money for it. The car wash pays $400. The remaining amount would be split between the 6 people equally. At the car washing, they earned $650. However, Brad didn't join the car purchase, how much more does each friend need to pay now that Brad's ​​off the hook?<n>- **Answer :** $230  <n><n>### Assignment:<n>Harper wants to buy a cappuccino maker for her son and daughter's teacher. Her son has 3 teachers, her daughter has 4 teachers. If she spent $ 60 on a gift, how much would each gift cost?<n>- **Answer - D** $ 10 per gift, she would spend a total of $200 on gifts<n><n>### Problem:<n>He wore the wrong shoestring during the day on foot He ended up with what on his toes and heels? - Choices:  A, walk  B, Locomotion C, exercise  D, blisters  E, foot<n>- **Answer : D** Blisters<n><n>```markdown<n>### Explanation<n><n>```markdown

Choices:  A: reverse B: backwards C: back and D: back and E: tally back<n><n>### Response:		<n>[A](https://i.stack.imgur.com/o4RK9.png)<n><n>### Input :  Find the difference in price between the lowest and highest price of the bottle of wine that is the highest in price and then round up the difference to the nearest multiple of 50. <n><n><n>#2 If you were building a website called "Worldwide Sushi Recipes", where you provide a database of all sushi recipes which anyone could download for free, what should your database design look like?<n><n>### Design:<n>![Database Design](assets/img/sushi_design.png)<n><n><n>### Design description:  Database with multiple columns and tables allows for multiple data to be stored in a single system, reducing redundancy and simplifying data. By allowing multiple recipes to be stored separately within the table, and to selectively combine the data for easy viewing.<n><n>### Challenges Design:<n>This design will not prevent or detect fraudulent activity in the sushi recipes because, while any user of the system could download a sushi recipe and copy and paste it, this would bypass the original intent of allowing any user free access to the information.<n><n>### Design enhancement:<n>By implementing a system that detects fraud, either by IP address or other method, the system will eliminate those with fraudulent intent. It will also allow the system to detect when a user has downloaded similar information repeatedly, thereby indicating a possible fraudulent intent to copy the data.<n><n>### Additional Information:<n>This is a solution to [Design an Ideal Sushi Recipe Website](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/71800056/design-an-ideal-sushi-recipe-website).<n><n>### Outputs:<n>[Image of a completed database.](assets/img/recipe_data_db.png)<n><n>[Design Document](Design\sushi_design2.pdf)<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response that explains how you designed your database with SQL.<n><n>### Response Requirements:<n>>Describe the concept and importance of database normalization.<n>[Normalization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_normalization#Normal_forms

An aquarium, or a sea, is not the place that you are likely playing. It makes sense that a pool is not a place to bet in since “bet” is not the word that a child or an adult in the ocean would use. The “pool hall” is where you bet on pool games. The pool “hall” is where you play pool games, but not where you bet.<n><n>### Input2:Write a sentence that ends with the word "drama". He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where do most people keep their curling iron stored? The human anatomy needs to be thoroughly looked at for more context. The purpose of this assignment is to help build basic understanding, so to find and present the best answer would require too much research (for this assignment at least). However, in the future, it would be interesting to look at more specific ways we intake human oxygen such as from food and things outside the body we bring in. Does the student identify a clear solution?<n>-Does the student reason through the answer?<n>-Does the response provide a clear solution to the problem?<n>-Can the student identify what he/she understands incorrectly?<n>-Does the solution provide more than one way to solve the problem?<n>-Does the answer answer completely the question?<n><n>### Explanation:<n> -For example, Khan Academy asks the kids to write a one digit number that equals the sum of the cube and the square of the number.  The student is to express the problem, write the solution, and write an explanation. The prompt should state that the prompt requires  clarity, accuracy, and precision.  There should be no spaces in the solution or the explanation.<n><n> -Codecombat for Kids asks the student to write a program that allows a pirate ship to shoot cannons. The student is first to identify which type of command to use.  The student is then to state whether or not the program will work. Then the student is asked to write the program that allows the ship to shoot cannions. Then the student writes a program where the cannons only shoot at the enemies.  Finally the student is asked to edit the program such that 1) if the ship doesn’t see an enemy, it doesn’t shoot its cannions. 2) If too many people are on the ship, the ship doesn’t fire its cannons. 3) If the people don’t fire their cannons and the ship is not running, they will receive negative reinforcement.<n><n><n>### Expectations:<n>1. How much did you make in three years?<n>### Output3: $1729<n>

Choices:  A: friendship B: aggression C: defeat D: winning or losing E: sweat<n><n>### Response:		The friends loved competiting with eachother, it was a good away to show their a. Friendship B. Aggression C. defeat d. Winning or losing E. sweat<n><n>## Tear Down<n>**Narrative**: A tear down is a document that explains how an artifact was created. A tear down can be used to understand exactly how your script was executed and to ensure that another developer can read your script and produce the same results on their device.<n><n>## Reuse<n>**Narrative:**Reusable code provides an immediate benefit to the developer who understands the code and has control of it. Reusable code improves maintainability and is a significant time saver when it comes to finding a needle in a haystack.<n>The following three guidelines are recommended as best practice for reusable code:<n><n>**Use code libraries.** Code libraries contain prewritten and tested code. This can speed up the development cycle by saving time researching, testing, and writing similar code.  Most programming languages have libraries that developers can access.  JavaScript also offers a vast library of free tools that can be used to reduce the time it takes to search and develop code. These are free on the Internet and can be downloaded into JavaScript, making the library available with every JavaScript source file.<n><n>**Extract and reuse pieces of code. By extracting the code and then putting it in a separate area, you have isolated the functionality. With this strategy, you have access to all the code that’s used to perform a task; therefore, if a need arises to perform it again, it can be easily reused. <n><n>**Reuse blocks of code.** This allows developers to reuse the same code in multiple applications or places in a program. This is accomplished using variable, function, and global variables.  This may be a better option than combining code and placing it in the program by using global variables.<n>## Example:<n>Here is some reusable code.  For example, you can see that the function `findWalruses()` takes one argument `walrusNr`. The function is designed to look for walruses and will use the `findWalrus()` function inside.<n>You can also notice the use of a `global variable`, which holds the position. This allows us to reuse this code by replacing the argument with `findWalrus()`.<n><n>```javascript<n>const myGlobalVar =

B: It’s more likely to be divisible by 25.<n><n>### Option  (b): It is more likely to be divisble by 7.  C: It is more likely a multiple of 8.<n><n>### Answer : a<n><n>### Option C<n><n>### Input(check all that apply):<n>### A: The temperature is 118. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is a fast but expensive way to send small cargo? How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is a useful activity when experiencing loneliness? Choices:  A: meet people B: meet friend C: make people laugh D: socialize E: liquor<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choose the best response. <n><n>```python<n>def main():<n>    # write a program for this choice.<n>    # the first element is a guess.<n>    # the second element is a positive integer.<n>    # after the user enters the guess, your program should display the next correct guess and the total guesses until right.<n>    # Example:<n>    #   3 2<n>    #   guess_total is 3, guess_correct is 2.<n>    #   24 2<n>    #   8 3<n>    #   3 -2<n>    #   total guesses-4, last guess correct=2<n><n>    guess_total = 0<n>    guess_correct = 0<n><n>    try:<n>        last_guess = int(input('Please enter your guess '))<n>    except:<n>        pass<n><n>    while last_guess!= 2:<n>        guess_correct += 1<n>        guess_total += 1<n>        last_guesses = last_guess<n>        last_guest = int(input('Guess your choice:'))<n>        if last_guest!= last_guess:<n>            if last_guest == 2:<n>                print('Your guess is correct! Total guesses:', guess_total)<n>            else:<n>                print('The answer is', guess_correct,' Your guess is:', last_guest, 'The answer is no.')<n>        if last_game==2:<n>            if last guess > 2:<n>                last guess = 0<n>            else:<n><n>                last_guesses = 2<n>                last_game += 1<n>                last_guess = 1<n>                last step = int(input('How many steps does the total time equal 15:'))<n>                current_step = 0<n>            while current_step!= last_step:<n>                print('Guess a number, it will go up 1 number every one game. Step',current_step,' is up next.')<n>                current_step += 1<n>                current_guest = int (input())<n>                if current_guest <= last_guest:<n>                    print('It got up one number more than it did.')<n>                    print(last_guest)<n>                    current_step += 2

Choices: <n>- A: in the front<n>- B: not well<n>- C: against<n>- D: for<n>- E: not<n><n>### Solution: C<n>- pro: for; against (prefix used to change sense/meaning of the root word)<n>

How old are Zach and Aaron? (The oldest person, 3 people, and 1 animal lived together).<n><n>There are multiple ways to get different answers when solving this problem using the multiplication properties.<n><n>### Choices<n>### A: 6 years old or 8 years old<n><n>### B: 4 years old<n><n>## Input<n>My dog has 6 bones in his backyard and my dog takes them in order.  <n>1: 4<n>2: 1<n>3:8<n>4:1<n>5:4<n>6:1<n>In how many days are the bones taken?<n><n>I think the solution to this is this:<n><n>If there are six numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 then there are 6 combinations each of them taken out there are 6 different combinations there is an even number since there is always only 1 in each position and 2 in each position<n><n>### Choice<n>### A:23

They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is KFC who serves chicken? Choices:  A: fast food restaurant B: plate C: bowl D: freezer E: oven<n><n>### Response:		You need to read the question carefully and think about how answer it. Choices:  A: pleasure B: delight C: bankruptcy D: agony E: owning<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Instructions: Complete the following task.<n><n>### Input<n><n>The chef has 60 jars of strawberry preserves but is out of jars.  He wants to get 3 jars of strawbery preserves but he only has 1 jar and 4 jars of peach preserves. If the chef gives 1 jar of peach to each of his siblings and 1 jar of strawberry to each of the people who share his name, then he can still get his jars. How many people are there with the same name as the chef?<n><n>### Response<n><n>The original problem was incomplete. The chef had 60 preserves but only 33 jars. It would have been smarter had he counted his jars and preserves.  He would have found that he had 27 extra peach preserves.  He then would have been able to send his jams to his siblings and pick out his strawbery jam.  It is now complete.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>1. The chef had 33 jars and 60 preserves, so he had 27 preserves and 7 jars<n>2. The chef gave 1 jar of peaches to each sibling 6 - 1 = 5<n>3. He gave 1 jar of stawbery to each person with his name 4 - 1 = 3<n>4. The chef now only needed to get the 3 preserves he was missing<n><n>### Input The two friends both like a pair of jeans selling for $32. The first friend buys the jeans but decides to share the cost and gives his friend a $13 gift certificate for use at a local clothing store.   How much did the friend who bought the jeans need to pay?<n><n>### Solution<n><n>The first friend paid $32 + $13 = $45 He spent $13 and gave $13 to his friend - $26<n><n>### Instagram post<n><n>> ## What are your thoughts?<n><n>* `First friend`

They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Wanting to avoid the cabbage spoiling, where did he put it? Choices:  A: grocery store B: refrigerator C: freezer D: plate E: supermarket<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input:(40 points) Which animal can have a heart attack? However, answers are either mathematical, not related to a computer, or a code to evaluate.<n>- The instruction, "Demonstration:", requires you to give a mathematical solution or explain a concept related to your code or project.<n>- If the instructions say "Instruction:Answer the following questions:" the question is what a person (student, judge, etc.) would be curious about regarding the task.<n>- "Instruction:Answer these multiple choice questions:" is similar to the "Instruction:" task but you must answer with a simple "yes or no," "it is true or false," or multiple choice questions.<n>- "Instructions for Review:" is not a task that you need to solve. It is just information for you to review.<n><n>### Note:<n>If you have any questions about where a task falls in the tutorial, feel free to ask on our [forum](https://community.codingame.com/t/codingame/410). The forum is the best place to contact us for questions about our lessons.

However, the letters of the word are also on the outer perimeter. If the word was placed in a circle, it would not be possible to have a 9 letter word that was fully to the left of the central point because the remaining letters are on the outside.

Choices:  A: two feet B: two ears C: horns D: lay eggs E: one head<n><n>### Response:		Write a JavaScript program that can process the request.<n><n><n>### Instance:<n><n>Input:The chef has 60 boiled eggs. He puts 20 eggs in the frig and uses the rest to feed his dog. If he used 4 eggs to feed his dog, how many eggs does he have left?<n><n><n>### Explanation:<n>```javascript<n>let eggs = 60;<n>let eggsLeft = eggs;<n><n>for(let i = 0; i < eggsLeft; i++)  {<n>    eggsLeft -= 2;<n>}<n><n>```<n><n>Output:<n>```javascript<n>Letter: 4  <n>Letter: A<n>```<n>### Question:<n>

He asks his mother to help cut it into thirds, fifths and tenths.  The mother asked if there was enough for a third.  Is this possible?<n>Answer: No, the cake is to be divided first into thirds and fifths.  A third of five is one fifth.<n><n>Input: Which of the following is a way to write 10^2? Choices: A: one hundred   B: ten   C: three   D: 20<n><n>### Response<n>C. Ten to the second power, thirty.<n><n>Input: A baker’s dozen is how many?   A:  11<n>B:  + 2<n>C: + 4 <n><n>### Response  <n>C. A Baker’s dozen has 13.  13  =  + 2<n><n>Input: What’s going on?   A:  I have to take a rest.  I’m just a little tired.  B:  I'm a little sleepy.  C:  I'm sorry. I have to take a short break.<n><n>### Response <n>A. I have to take on a rest, I'm just a little tired = I have to take a nap. <n><n>Input.The chef has 10 eggs. He puts one egg in the fridge. The eggs left are used to make cakes. Each cake has 4 eggs.  How many eggs are left after all 4 eggs are used?<n><n>### Response   <n><n>B. The chef has 9 eggs after he puts one egg in the refrigerator. Each cake used 4 eggs, leaving him with 12 more eggs, (9 + 12 = 21)<n><n>Input: A boy has 4 marbles. Each week 2 more marbles are given by the grandpa. How many marbles does this boy have after 12 weeks?<n><n>### Option<n><n>### Response     <n>A. B. (2*12)

You can solve as many or as few as you'd like.<n><n># Task 2<n>Write a program in Java that uses a text file as an input file. This value is stored in a student object. After reading through your file, save what you found out in a student object, printing the name, quizzes, and grade. The end.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>![](/sample1.png)<n><n>### Instruption:Solve the following task.<n><n>### Solve by example:<n><n># Task 3<n>Write a program in Haskell that allows the user to enter a string, then print, “Your string is:”, followed by the string with the letters capitalized.<n><n>## Sample Input: <n>Input: Your string is: Hello World<n><n>## Sample Output:<n>Your string is: HELLO WORLD<n><n>### Instraction:Complete the following task.<n>Solve by example:<n>---<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Billy's mother tripped over a stuffed animal.  She yelled at him not to leave his things where? Choices:  A: toy store B: hall C: bathroom D: amusement park E: fairgrounds<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Answer B<n><n>### Rationale:  (write 2-3 sentences to explain the why.)<n>This is because she was tripped on the floor near his bed which were close and accessible to him therefore his toys are to be put away in the bathroom when he is done playing with it.  If a toy is dropped by the toddler/child somewhere else, it will be harder to find it with time and he/she might stumble on it.<n><n><n>---<n>© 2018 Trilogy Education Services, a 2U, Inc. brand. You will be given a task and need to write the correct code along with the steps to do so.<n><n>## Task: You are allowed to use at most **40** lines of code and your code must fit the following constraints:<n> - **At most 30 spaces** (not including the blank lines between statements)<n> - **At most ** 10** print statements**<n> - **All statements should be indented**<n> - **All variables should be single letter**.<n> - The code should make sense and read well - be clear and concise<n><n>---<n><n>![](https://docs.google.com/uc?export=view&id=16DY07HmX2hcZKJrkdI0Fu8pJYpVK4CW)<n><n>--<n><n>![](https//docs.google.com.au/file/d/1qHb0wuI4iW-XIWO2YZkE2l-r2gMu0QXcL6rYRj_vTs0QgWKo6wLg8EZkRKMJgX5FzgT/edit?usp=sharing)<n><n>###<n><n>* Instruction:<n>* Your first step would be to import the numpy in Python. The way to do this is as<n>  - Import numpy<n><n>* Your second step would be to create an empty 2-D array<n><n>Your third step would be to fill your first dimension with random numbers<n><n>* Your fourth step would be to fill the second dimension of your array with random numbers<n><n>You would have to put brackets (braces) around the dimensions<n><n>* You would then need to create a 2-D function that would return a new<n>    element of your 2-D array to use in your program.<n>* You would need to use the numpy.transpose() function to flip your<n>    matrix

The value of a variable is set to 4.  What would a value of -3 be when the variable is incremented (or added) by 1? 2. The value of a number is 17. If it is subtracted by 2, what number would it equal? 3. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Choices:  A: vessel B: box C: transistor D: submarine E: lamp<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Answer the question<n><n>- 1. Richard and Hurley are 16 and 6 respectively 40 years from the<n>present.<n><n>- 2. Pablo's mother agreed to pay him $1 a page<n><n>- 3. The cost $1700, the six friends will split equally the<n>total cost $30 as follows. $300=$1700 divided by 6<n><n>$$\therefore\;\;\;\;\;$$<n>$$A\;+\;4\;=\;3\;$$<n><n>- 4. Cost for each child is $10<n><n>- 5. The chef had 50 eggs; He needed 5 eggs for each cake,<n><n>\$\therefore\;\;  \;\;\;\;\;50\;=\;5\;(1\;+\;5)\;\;\;\;\;$<n><n>$$\therefroe\;5\;+\;55\;=\;55\;+\;25\;$$

Write a function named "multiplyTwoNumbers" that takes in two numbers as arguments and returns the product.The function should follow the code below:<n>	<n>	```<n>	 function multiplyTwoNumbers (num1, num2)<n>	 return num1*num2;<n>```<n>2. For your exercise, call your function and multiply together 5 and 8.<n>	<n>	```JavaScript<n>	(function multiplicatortwoNumbers(x,y){<n>	return x*y;<n>	}<n>	) (5,8) // 40<n>	```<n>### Demonstation :<n>```<n>    example:<n>    (function multiplyTwoNumbers(x,y)<n>    return x*y;<n>    ) (5,8)   result: 40<n>    1. write a function name multiplyTwoNumbers that contains two numbers as argument and return the product<n>     2. for your exercise call the multiplyTwoNumbers and multiply together five and eight<n>```<n>### Demostration:<n><n>The above demonstration is a code solution of the question that shows the answer steps and describes this question completely. Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:James was cooling off two quickly. He is trying to redo the deck on the second story of the house.  The railing needs to be the height of three and a half feet, the post is fifteen inches wide and is sixteen feet long.  Hurley can place one rail 18 times from start to finish, so how many feet of railing does he need in order to make the whole railing?<n><n>### Response<n>Hurley will need to create 24 pieces of railings to complete the stair.  Hurleys railings are 2 foot long which is 36 inches.  If the deck is 16 feet long multiplied by 18 sections that is 324 inches.  Divide 324 by 36 to find the answer of 9 sections which Hurley needed to redo the stairs.<n><n>### Input

It is not just by finding the sum of a previous two numbers but each numbers of the previous to find the next number of a sequence.<n><n>### Response<n>6<n>1 is the a gap from 3 and 2 and 9 (sum = 6) in sequence has a 6 to go with it.<n><n>### You get 2 points for every question you get right.

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:I'm looking for alcohol and fried foods, any suggestions? Choices:  A: pub B: plane C: beer D: store E: fraternity house<n><n>### Response:		Plane, Fraternity house<n>### Reason:You wrote a statement wherein the letter "e" is in the words "fraternity" and "food", and the letter "f", in the word "food", is in the same group with the letter "w", which is present in the word "plane", thus making the statement true.<n><n>

Choices:  A: break easily B: shattering C: melt D: bend E: hold water<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Demostration:Thin glass means that the thickness of the glass is small. Also, it is light in weight. When it falls down from a higher level, the glass may easily break. In contrast, thick glass is not easily broken and is therefore suitable for construction and use in household appliances. In short, thick glass is suitable for construction and use while thin glass is not.<n><n>### Input:#. Select the missing number from the choices provided. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What could prevent someone from buying chistmas presents? Choices:  A: happiness B: lack of money C: stress D: relief E: exhiliration<n><n>### Response:		<n>C  A few hours into the day, when one is finally done being productive and/or chilling, one starts to feel overwhelmed by the fact that there will not be [enough time or enough money] to buy everyone everything that they want from their list - especially if they intend to buy a gift for their family or friends, too. Not only will they have [less money] but they will have less time! That's when one feels a sense of relief and relaxation by coming to the realization that there is no longer a need to stress so much about it.<n><n>### Review:<n>You may want to review this chapter if you need help.<n>

If the people in the circle are described as having a diameter of ten meters, then there are 120 people in the circle. The remaining choices are each synonyms of "diameter of"<n><n>### Input  :  The answer choice (D): "If you want to get to the mountain, you have to walk through the valley." is not a synonym of "traverse" (as some dictionaries define a "synonym", it must be a different word with the same or similar meaning). However choice (b) "ascend" is a perfectly cromulent word that describes the action of getting (going) from one place to another. It is important to remember that a synonym or antonym is not a complete synonym because it only describes another word in whole or in part.<n><n>### Input	:  The answer choice (E): "The correct answer is Choice (B): (b) 13. If there were 10, 100 dollar bills, how many of each denomination of bill did the cashier give?<n><n>### Response 100 bills with face values of $30.20 and 10 bills with a face value of $3.80.<n><n>### Explanation:The cashier gives change in 35 dollar bills, so there must be at least 35 bills (or 10 groups of 3). Then the cashier has to have a remainder of some kind. Let’s consider some possibilities: If there are two bills remaining, then the cashier gave 20 $3s and 5 $1s. If there are four bills remaining, then she gave 15 $3s and 4 $1s. If she gives 8 bills, she must have left the store with $20 in change to cover the remainder. This leaves one possibility for the remainder, if there are 8 $3 bills, 4 $1 bills, and 1 $0.20 bill.<n><n>### Question:<n><n>### Input 2<n><n>### Exercise 3<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Use your knowledge of multiplication properties to show that 10 * 4 =140.<n><n>## Submission:<n>Submit your response through the "Exercise 3" field.<n>

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What could happen after driving car that does not involve pain? Choices:  A: automobile accidents B: backache C: eye strain D: getting tired E: car crash<n><n>### Response:		After driving a car for many hours, a car can’t really hurt us unless the car crashes. The other possible outcomes that may follow driving a car involve only pain, backache, eye strain and tired. I don’t see any of them as pain, the backache only follows sitting on the car for too long while driving, the eye strain can occur when the headlights shine on the eyes, and the tiredness occur when the car is idle and the engine is on and it is no use driving the car.  That means the car in which we sit is doing all the work without us, however, driving to our destination make us tired.  The other outcomes can’t also be counted as pain because they can occur at any time or place with or without us driving a car which contradicts the requirements of the question.  So the only possibility should be the car crash which in itself is a form of pain.

Choices: A: Mexico B: Brazil C: France D: Spain E: Germany<n><n>### Response The answer the student is looking for for this question is E Spain. The student also has too type the name of the continent that the country is from. They also need to include the student's full answer.<n><n><n>### Input What is the length between Alaska and Hawaii? Answer Choices: A: 1,900 miles B: 2,500 miles C: 3,300 miles D: 4,100 miles E: 4,700  miles<n><n>### Response <n>The student is asking for the distance between these 2 states. They not only need to include the distance <n>but the student has to include the miles or the kilometers. The student also does not need to include which unit is being <n>used, but if they are answering in miles. They need to include the distance in miles. If they are answering in kilometers, <n>they need to use to word "kilometers" in their answer.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:i like to examine different things,why do books the chapters on the back Choices:  A: examine thing B: go somewhere C: knit D: read book E: see particular program<n><n>### Response:		A->Examine thing,B->Go somewhere,C->Knit,D->Read books,E->See particular program

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The obsessive man was always washing hands, he had even done it so much once that it caused a what? Choices:  A: use soap B: irritation C: cleanliness D: thinking E: wet towel<n><n>### Response:		<n>> The obsessive man was even washing his hands so much once that it causes the dry hands.<n><n>## Description<n><n>You are given an array of data; answer a question with the data.<n><n>### Answer the following multiple choice question correctly (you will be ejected if you answer incorrectly).<n><n>### Example Demonstration<n><n>This instruction is an incorrect example of how you should structure your response.<n><n>### Solution:<n>Here is a valid answer structure to questions.<n>Here is an invalid structure, so the bot might reject this and ask for a different solution or even just say there is no answer.<n>It's because of the difference between if and while. If you use a for loop with a while loop inside, you can't have an else:<n>while <expression> do<n>while <expression>2 do(do nothing)<n>end<n><n>### Question:<n>Given the list of strings: "hello" "silly" "monkey" "dolphin" "unicorn" "panda" "dragon", how many unique (meaning only one copy) words with 4 or less letters appear in the list?<n><n>### Hint:<n>You can use Python's set() function to return a new list with unique values passed into the function.<n>### Answer:<n>There are 10 unique words with 4 or fewer letters.<n><n>### Question 2:<n>"You have 3 blue, 2 yellow and 1 red pinkie rings. You want to make a yellow ring in 6 minutes. How long will it take to make a blue ring?"<n><n>### Hints for Question 2:<n><n>- If we multiply the time to make one blue ring by the number of blue rings:<n>	6 * (number of blue rings) = hours<n>	<n>- If I need to make one yellow ring in 10 hours, then how many hours does it take to make the last yellow ring: 10 - (10 ÷ 2) = 15 hours<n>	<n>If I multiply the number of blues rings by 15 hours, the answer will probably be too large. So subtract the original time to make one yellow ring. Which leaves 6 minutes for the blue rings (I don't care, so I'll just subtract it).<n><n>### Solution<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Choices:  A: buy athletic equipment B: city C: espn D: town E: jerseys<n><n>### Response:		<n>- A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>You will need to create at least two new methods in order to finish this challenge.<n><n>### Methods:<n>A method is a group of statements that can be executed once or in sequence depending on their purpose.  The methods must include a specific name, number of parameters, a method definition and 0 or more expressions.<n><n>-   A method must have a name that has not been used before<n>  -   If your method was a definition of an object then the name must be different and not equal to another object that is a definition of the same object.<n>  <n>-   A method can have up to 1 parameter  <n>  <n>-   The purpose of the parameter is to call the method, it is not a field of the object<n>  -   The parameter can be a method or the name of an object and it can be either or the same name as a method in the class<n>  <n>-   An expression is a mathematical or logical evaluation that may be a calculation or an operation<n>  -   The purpose of an expression is to be used to assign one or more  values to a variable or be part of a test to determine conditions.<n>-   An expression may be a combination of multiple expressions<n>  -   An expression can be used to define a condition<n><n>An expression cannot have variable that are not defined as fields<n><n>### Demand 2<n>When a method is called, you first initialize the variables to define the objects that are called. Then, if the method requires additional variables or fields, you may define them as fields of the object or as parameters to the method. You should use assignment operators to define the newly defined fields. The definition of the method should be followed by a return statement with the value that you want to return if the method is successful. If the method is unsuccessful, return a statement may indicate failure by assigning a value or the empty string. <n>You can call a method before or after it can be defined. If you are using the assignment operator and have defined fields as parameters, then assign the parameters to define the objects.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>#### Class:<n><n>```javascript<n>const storeLocations = [];<n><n>///The Object definition for the store class. If  he races in the 100-meter,  and wins with a time of 11.8 sec, what time did he have in the 500-meter?<n><n>Answer: 59.80 sec<n><n>### Rational:<n><n>The man won in 11.8 seconds so he can deduce that he could spend 43.2 seconds in the 50-meter race.<n><n>Since time is inversely proportional, the man could race the 500 meter in 59.8 sec, or 9.8 times faster than the 100 meter race.<n><n>### Input:<n><n>A person wants to sell a new car that costs $21,950. There is nothing left if all taxes are paid, and the dealer keeps $3,336 for himself to compensate for his effort. What is the remaining money after paying the buyer his new tax?<n><n>### Output:<n><n>7.05<n>### Answer:<n><n>1. Subtracting $21,900 from the whole price ($21,95), leaves $300.<n>2. Dividing $3,330 by the whole number, $21,910, leaves $2,13, because $3,33 divided by $21,9 equals 2.13. <n>3. Adding $7.00 to $2,13 or $2,13 + $7.00 = 7.

Output: Area of trapezoid = 72m2<n>```<n>public class Trapezoid {<n>	public static void main(String[] args) {<n>		//Write your code here<n>		//Input<n>		double width, length, height;<n>		System.out.print("Enter width: ");<n>		width = sc.nextDouble();<n>		System.console().println(width + " meters");<n>		System.err.println("In the next line, enter length. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where do farmers keep toothpicks? Choices:  A: mouth B: grocery store C: constructing models D: shed E: box<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:Complete each challenge below.<n><n>### Challenges<n>There are two types of challenges:<n>- **Demonstrations:** A demonstration asks you to write code to perform a specific function. The response is expected to be a full Python program. (A few demonstrations are also followed by a "response" option.)<n>- **Multiple Choice**: Chooses one or more of the above listed options, depending on the challenge.<n><n>### How It Works<n><n>After you begin a challenge, you will see a question or a multiple choice question. If it asks you to provide code, your response must be a fully-written Python program. <n><n>After you write your code, click **Check Answers**, and then the computer will show you a red mark next to the incorrect answers. After the incorrect answers are marked, click **Next** on the bottom of your screen to move on to the next challenge.<n><n>You should always read the challenge carefully before you provide your response<n>1. To navigate the steps, click Next or Previous on your screen.<n>2. To go back and review the challenge, click Back on your screen.<n>3. Always check your work by clicking Check Answers in every challenge.<n>4. After you submit your response, you should see a green checkmark with **I'm done!**.<n><n>**If you need a little help…** Just click [Contact Me](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xQ268Q-n9YGgF_17Yh-yK57s9hZqEo3XnC6lGUUqmUA/edit?usp=drivesdk) to reach out to your instructor. <n><n>### How to Use This Section<n><n>To return to previous sections from the Challenge Workshop, use the links above. You are not expected to start at the beginning of each section, you may choose to pick up at any point on the flow. That being said here is the section order with links below:<n>1. How much did you save by making the trip?<n><n>### Input Choices:  $12 $10 $14 $8<n><n>The response has to include all the statements about each choice.<n><n>### Input Instruction: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Input<n>The doctor’s bill was $300 and insurance paid $250. What is the patient responsible for?<n><n>### Responses:   A: The patient owes $20.  B: The patient owes the doctor $50. C: The doctor owes the patient $50. D: The patient owes insurance $25.<n><n>### Respondents have to write responses for each of the above statements.<n><n>### Sample Input<n>Input: The doctor’s bill was 800 dollar and insurance paid the remaining amount. Now how much bill is remaining for the patient?<n><n>### Sample Responses<n>Response 1: The doctor’s original bill was $800 and insurance covered $250 of it. The patient is now $550 away from paying the full amount, which is $1350.<n><n>Response 2: The remaining amount is $(250 + 300) – 550 = $200<n><n><n>### Sample Instruction<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: The doctor's bill was $320 and insurance paid the rest. How much did the patient owe?<n>Answer: $30<n><n>The doctor’s original bill $320 was what insurance covered?<n><n>Response: $190<n><n>The patient’s owed bill $320, after insurance covered $190. <n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choices<n><n>### Demo<n>The doctor's bill was $(320 + 80) - 30 = $110<n><n>## Input: What comes next in the sequence? Choices:  A: open meadow B: arctic tundra C: beach D: great outdoors E: england<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input<n>A: open meadow<n><n>### Response<n>The only animal that would hunt a fox in a meadow is another fox. A fox hunt is most likely going to happen in a forest.<n><n>### Input <n>B: arctic tundria<n><n>### Response <n>A tundra is an open, undisturbed area of land.  However, there are no trees in the arctic tundra, so there's no hiding for a fox there.<n><n>###Input<n>C: beach<n><n>###Response<n>There aren't many predators at a beach and most animals would swim away if a fox tried to hunt them.  The only animals that would possibly be foxes' prey on the beach would be tiny little fish.<n><n>###Response <n>D: great outdoors<n><n>###Response I am confused about this answer.  A fox hunts during the night and the great outdoors is daytime.<n><n>### Response E: england<n>A fox hunt is a recreational activity in England that dates back hundreds of years.  During a hunt, fox hunters and their hounds chase animals that they suspect of eating livestock.<n><n>### Task<n><n>Below are instructions that describe multiple choice exercises.<n><n>### **Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question**<n><n>Input: ______ <n><n>### **Demonstration:**<n>Input: _____ <n>### **Response:**<n>    The answer to the problem is <n><n>### Task:Input: Where could you find a foxtail when not in a forest Choices:  A B C D E<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: _____<n><n>### Response.<n><n>### The Answer:<n><n>### Input.<n><n>### A: open meadow<n>### Response. ______ <n>### Input. Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:When a newborn's eyes open for the first time it will be the first time the ever? Choices:  A: tear up B: see light C: fill with tears D: be happy E: glass over<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is "fill with tears."<n><n>### Reason: Option (A) refers to an inanimate item - eyes are not tear-able - tears are liquid and eyes cannot be filled with liquid.<n><n>### Option (B) refers to an abstract concept - it is impossible to see something with nothing in your eyes.<n><n>### Options (C) and (D) refer to emotional states, which depend upon experience which the newborn hasn't had yet - they cannot truly be happy nor sad for the first time, so can't see light or cry.  They will be happy but won't know it, and they will cry but won't know that either.<n><n>### Difficulty: Hard<n>

First, let's talk about where the code goes.  <n><n>**Fork**: We used [JS Bin](https://jsbin.com/) to host our solutions.  [JS Bin](https:/jsbin.com/) is one of our favorites for hosting code.  <n> - You'll want to [fork a repo](https://doc.jsbin.com/ukuyax/1/edit) on JS Bin before you start writing.<n> - Once you've forked the repo, click `Browse File` which can be found after you've clicked `edit` on your fork.<n> - Next, you'll want to add a script file to the root. A `script.js` file should do.<n><n>**Add Code**:  Next, click `File` then `new`.  This will allow you to enter your code.<n><n>**Include Code:** You'll want to ensure that you have a `main.js` in the root directory of your repo.  Here, you'll [add your functions](https://dev.to/sturgeonsoftware/adding-functions-to-jquery-3w1y).  <n><n>Note: if you'd like to add code to your `script.js` it's best (in this case) to call it from `main.js`. However, there's no need to make the call in that case, as you're already in the function.<n><n>**Run Code:** In order to see your code work, simply click the run button for `main.js` for a step

What is the amount John has?<n><n>### Solution<n>Input: A. If we assume that 5 coins are 100 cents and 3 coins are 60 cents. Then total worth of the coins would be 160 cents. Remaining 40 cents can be accounted for as two coins with 20 cents value and the remaining 20 cent as the other coin.<n>Output: (A: 160 cts (2 X 40 cts and 3 (40 cts)) or (B: 160 + (2 X 4) cts = 160 cps))<n><n>### Comments:<n>1. It is always difficult to determine which solution is correct.<n>2. However, since B. solution seems correct based on a number of reason, we are going with it :)<n><n><n>### Input<n>> E. 50% of the people would rather be in a war. Choices:  A: bollywood B: record C: musical D: jukebox E: napster<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### The movie had many a song is a phrase that refers to a movie that contains many songs. Choices A, B, and C contain nouns, but the sentence has a verb in the form of "is" so it does not make sense for any choice that ends in a noun. (D) "jukebox" is not a phrase, rather it is a noun. A correct word pair is "the movie had many a song (noun), it was a musical" ("what", if followed by a noun, is called an interrogative pronoun.)<n><n>### Input:"I need to find the largest number that I can purchase with $15. What number should I buy?" What should I buy?<n><n>### Response<n><n>### The numbers $15 and the largest number that $15 can obtain (the largest is determined to be 6) are part of an English phrase called a "which phrase." "What number should I buy?" is also a phrase, one with a noun phrase and a verb phrase interlinked with the word "that".<n><n>### Input"I need to find the highest number that is divisible by five. What number should I look at?" What should I look at?<n><n>### Answer <n><n>### The phrase: "What number should I look at" is called interrogative phrase. Another phrase within the sentence, "I need to find the..." is called an English phrase.<n><n>### Input""I need to find the two largest odd numbers that add up to 24." What would the two numbers be?<n><n>### The best answer here is to write: "The two numbers would be 12 and 12." <n><n>### Input "I need to find two numbers with a sum of 6. That sum is 4 plus 2. What numbers can I choose?" Choices: 1+3, 2+4<n><n>### The correct phrase is 2+2. The sentence starts with an English phrase ("I need to find two...") and ends in another. "That sum is" is considered a verb phrase, as it starts with "Is" but ends in "sum" which is the name of a noun. The correct verb pair is "that sum" = "is."<n><n>### Input <n><n>### I need to multiply these

Choices:  A: read B: passenger C: land plane D: fly the plane E: buy tickets<n><n>### Response:		Input:<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>```swift<n>if input == "A"{<n>	print("Option A: People read while they are on a plane before they can use electronica")<n>}else if input == "B"{<n>	print( "Option A: People read when they are on a plane.<n><n>Option B: People wait in the plane before they can use Electronics")<n>}else if (input == "C" or input == "D"){<n>	print(Option A: People read before they can use electroncis.<n>Option B: People don't wait and read on the plane.<n>Option C: People wait to use electronics on the plane")<n>}else if ((input == "E" or input == "F")){<n>	print("When people fly they are not allowed to do electronics.<n>  Option A: Passengers read while they are on the plane.<n>  Option B: Passengers travel<n>  Option C: People are bored when they fly<n>  Option D: People wait a long time for a response before they can go on a plane.")<n>}<n>```<n>- If<n>- Else If<n>- Else<n><n>### Input A: How many hours was 18 months into hours?<n>Input A: 300 hours<n><n>```swift<n>//Answer<n>let timeInHours = String(input)!.split( separator: " " )[1]<n>let year = Int(timeInHours)!= nil<n>let month = Int(timeInhours)! /12<n>let time = Int(timeInYear)! * 365<n>printf("A. %ld", Double(time)! + Double(month)! )<n>```<n><n>### Input B How many people are in a room that has 5 windows?<n><n>```swift<n>let windowCount = sting.split(separator: " " )[0]<n>```<n><n>Input  B: 3<n><n>### InputC: How many books are in a bookshelf that has 7 shelves and 28 books?<n><n>```swift-<n>let input = sting.split(" "," (".range(end: 11, 11).map( String.init )<n><n>input.compactMap { $0 }.joined(separator: " ")<n>

It is the sixth car in the car park. <n><n>### Response<n>- Choices: A<n><n>### Input (answer is a sequence of natural numbers starting with one)<n><n>1. Select  one item from each category. <n>2. Choices:  A: article B: adjective C: interjection D: conjunction E: pronoun<n><n>### Response:		The answer is D or CONJUNCTION.<n><n>* Conjunction is used to connect grammatically two words. It is an article that connects words as one.<n>* It can be used to join words that are opposites as in the following sentence:<n>I have found the missing person, but what was their purpose in going missing?<n><n>* Examples of the conjunction: and, or, nor, but, because, if, whether, while, even though<n><n>* The above are not only conjunctions but they can also be either prepositions or pronouns.<n><n>### Input 2:<n>Which is the correct word for the bold one? <n><n>A: There. There is a great deal of work for me to do. <n><n>B: To it. To the work, there is a great deal of<n><n>C: Their. There is a great detail in their report. <n>   <n>D: Their. There is a great difficulty in their schedule. <n><n>Answer: A or THERE. <n><n>A: In the sentence: There is a great deal (differentiate between 'd' and 'deal') of work for me to (means 'for/to somebody/something') do, the correct word is THERE.<n><n>### Comment:<n>This task is very simple and easy to be done even for the beginners, however it gives a good idea on how to choose the correct word among the other synonyms.<n><n>## Instruction 3:<n>Which choice is correct in the sentence?<n><n>The manager needs to make sure that all of his employees have finished making the product or else all of them will be fired.<n>A: The manager needs to make sure... have finished<n>B: The manager needs to ensure that...have finished the making<n>C: The manager needs to be sure.... have finished the job<n>D: The manager needs to complete the job before he make sure... have finished making<n><n>The sentence means: The manager needs to check (mean is make sure)  that all of his employees (mean is 'all of them') has finished (mean finished) the job (mean is making the product), or else all of them (mean 'all of them') will be fired. <n><n>The above answer is C or THE MANAGER NEEDS TO BE SURE...HAVE FIN

He will not increase the number of books he owns.  How many books will he have now?<n><n>### Response
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where can you find a place to eat and places to buy items of many different kinds? Choices:  A: city B: downtown C: own house D: bar E: shopping center<n><n>### Response:		Answer A<n><n>### Explanation to question 1:<n>If Hurley is 16 years old, their combined ages 48 years from now would be 2.0 x (16 x 48) plus Hurleys age.<n>2.0 x (24 x 48) + 16 =692+16 = 708<n><n>### 1st Example<n> If Hurley is 5 years old, the combine ages would be 2.5 x 5 + 25 because you can multiply 2.0 by (5x48) and then rounding up a 128 because it is 128 and you do not round up.<n><n>### 2nd Example<n>If Pablo is reading books that that are exactly 140, then they need to know how many do they need to read to add up to 150. We have 150 - 140 to equal 10, the 10 would be equal to the candy in dollars or pages.<n><n>### Expert task: What other variables could you use to solve for the number answered?<n><n>### Expected Output:<n>You are done!<n><n>### Instructions: Write a short, response that includes all of the following.<n>- A statement that describes if what you found for the question is right.<n>- How you found your answer.<n>- What else you would do to find a different answer for the question.<n>- Explain your answer using the example of the question you answered.<n>### Your response goes here<n>What other variable could be used to find an item?<n>I would multiply this item by a factor but that is it. It's just to show you how you can go about find an item by using the variable.<n><n>### Question 2<n>You can do it from any of these points because you are just multiplying the two answers with each other and adding or subtracting to find out if it equals or not <n><n>### Examples<n>Example 1<n>Example 2<n>Example 3<n>```<n>
