Choices:  A: bus stop B: graph C: post office D: grass E: play<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Answer:A<n><n>## Constraints & Key Features<n><n>-  All responses must contain the same text in the same format as the instruction.<n>- All responses must satisfy the specifications stated in the instruction above<n>- You must answer each part of an instruction.<n>-  You need to add text for each part of the instruction and not just answer “yes” or “no”.<n>- Your responses must satisfy the structure and context.<n>-  You must read all parts of instructions.<n><n>### How am I going to achieve this? <n><n>- I will be using the instructions to create a new conversation thread. <n>- I will use the conversation thread to create new objects.<n>- I will then use the objects to create replies.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>### Input<n>Here is how to make pizza.<n><n>### Response<n>Mix the dough until it's nice and fluffy.<n>Then, spread it in a pan that's at least 12 inches across, and bake it in a<n>350-degree Fahrenheit oven for half an hour.<n><n>If you're in a rush to have dinner, you can top the dough with tomato slices.<n><n>- I will write a template that uses variables so I don't have to include the same response for each instruction.<n><n>### Here are the objectives:<n>- For each of the instructions, create a new object in the conversation thread. <n><n>### Here is the structure:<n><n>### Object<n>- {Conversation Thread}<n>  - {Instruction}<n>    - {Variable}<n><n>### Object properties:<n>- {Text}<n>- {Number}<n>- {Boolean}<n><n>### Here's what's going to happen after I have those object properties :<n><n>### Replies<n>- {Object} : <n>  - {Instructions}<n><n>### How will I add those variables?<n><n>### I will be using the following variables:<n>"Here is the text of the conversation."<n>"It is an object."<n>"It is a boolean value (true or false)."<n>"It is a number."<n>"It is text."<n><n>### Example of variables<n><n>### The response<n><n>### The structure<n>

Choices:  A: shake hands B: control events C: talk to each other D: think creatively E: dress themselves<n><n>### Response:		I will select option E because this answer shows that people in class had to use their minds to create creative answers to the questions that were posed to them. This would make the most sense in order to answer this question about the brainstorming process and how people use their minds in this way at school when they are learning about a topic or are presented with an open-ended question and how they use their minds to create new ideas that could help them solve a puzzle or come up with an appropriate response in order to show what they know about the material at hand.<n><n>Input: What is the product of 3 x 4?<n>Answer: 24<n><n>Input: What number goes into the 3rd box if all three boxes are filled up?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: What do you get when you add 6 to the product of 4 and 9?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: What numbers go into the same box?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>### Instructions:<n>When presented with an algebraic expression, select the correct statement to describe the expression.<n><n>### Examples:<n>Input: 12 x 20<n>Answer: A whole number<n><n>Input: 4x25-6<n>Answer: A negative number<n><n>### Response/Suggestion:If the question reads, which of the following is a whole number? The answer would be all of the choices, since a whole number can include a number between 1 and 100. If you are looking at the expression 4x25 - 6 then the result is a negative number since the sum of the number 4 and the number 25 minus the number 6 is -14.<n>

They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The man wanted to take a bus, but all the chars were full of people doing what? Choices:  A: sitting down B: refusing C: saving money D: sit down E: go outdoors<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input :You like to read books. Your favorite authors range from Charles Dickens to Agatha Christie. In total, you read a book by an author for the first time every 1 in 2 years. You keep your reading logs on 3-by-5 inch index cards. In how many bookshelves will you need to hold your collection?<n><n>### Response :  A<n><n>### Instrcution : A computer programmer's hobbies include cooking and reading mystery novels. If the programmer plays 2 mystery novels and reads 1 cookbook, how many books will be read?<n><n>### Responce :B<n><n>### Instructions: An artist creates two identical pieces of art. She places 1 of her pieces on the left side of the street and places the other one on the right. In how many directions will a person have traveled if they follow a pathway between the two pieces of art?<n><n>### Input 1 68<n><n>### Output 2 3<n><n>### Explanation: 68 and 68 are at angles of 0, 180, but it is unclear whether the streets are perpendicular to each other, so the answer is two<n><n>###Instructions: A group of friends went on a trip together. The trip included a car ride, a bus ride, a boat ride, and a plane ride. They made a single payment covering the travel. The total cost of the trip was $35. How much does each mode of travel cost?<n><n>###Input: 8<n><n>###Output: 2.5, 3, 2.5, and 1<n><n>###Explanation: Travelling by car is twice as expensive as travelling by plane, travelling by bus and travelling by boat<n>- Car = 2 x $2 = $4<n>- Boat = 2 x $0.75 = $1.5<n>- Bus = 2 x $1 = $2<n>- Plane = 1 x $2.5 = $2.5<n>

Choices:  A: overhead compartment B: chair C: hospital D: in shirt E: business meeting<n><n>### Response:		<n>A – overhead compartment, D – business meeting, A – overhead compartment, C – hospital, <n>A – overhead compartments, B – business meeting, A - overhead compartment<n><n>Answer:<n>A<n><n>### Reasoning:<n>Each choice mentions something the attache would typically come in contact with.<n><n>I would say that the attache would come in contact with the attache case and the business meeting<n><n>## Evaluation:<n>What did you think of this task?<n><n>It made sense but it was harder than the others.<n><n><n><n>-[x] Checked in to this project.<n><n>-[x ] Confirmed you want to be an [Alphabet](https://alphabet.github.io/).<n>-[x] Read the [instructions](https://github.com/fairwren/cs101s21-project2/blob/master/instructions.md).<n>-[x] Updated your [README.md](https://fairwren.github.io/cs101-S21-project2-fairwren/Readme.md).<n>- [ ] Found and used the [example GitHub project](https://github.github.io/projects-example/README.md).<n>- [] Submitted your project to the instructor.<n>- [] Provided constructive feedback to the project of a peer.<n>- [] Used GitHub in an effective manner.<n>- [x] Used your time effectively and met this goal.<n>- [] Demonstrated mastery of the topic by going beyond an expected or required scope (e.g. demonstrates command of all key course topics, not just those related directly to the project)<n>

He lives on his own. Where does he live? Choices:  A: fish market B: pet shop C: great outdoors D: river E: little mermaid<n><n>### Response:		<n>C. Cakes<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>When the chef needs 60 eggs to bake his 10 cakes, he must have an excess of 50 eggs remaining. This number can be divided (50/2), which leaves each egg only needed for baking 1/4 of a cake.<n><n>### InputThe chef has 3 candy bars. He gives 1/2 of the candy to one of his friends and gives the remaining candy bar to his brother.  How many candy bars did he have at the end?<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Examplaion:<n><n>When he first gives 1/2 the candy away, he now has half of 3, which is 1 1/2 candy bars. This means if he gives 1 to his friend and the remaining candy bar (1 1/2 - 1) to his brother, he now has 1 1/4 candy bars remaining.<n><n>### Exercise<n><n>Write or comment out the statements that are needed in the exercise.<n><n>This exercise asks students to identify an expression/question and write a response.<n><n>### Prompt: What is the difference<n><n>### Example:<n>Write a description of how the difference is calculated for the above example.<n><n>### Solution:First, 1/2 of 3 is taken. After, 1/2 is subtracted from 1/2, which leaves an answer of 1 1/8. Then, 1 is added, which leaves 1 1/7<n><n>### Write a description of how the equation is solved, using words and symbols if needed for the example given here.<n><n>### Solution: 1/4 x (1/2-1) = 1/4(3/2)-1 = 1/4*3/4-1 = (1/2-4/4) -1 = 1/2 -1.5 = 1/3 -1.5 = (1/3) -1.5 =1/5<n><n>### Exercises<n><n>1.What is the sum of 48 and 7?<n>2.Add one dozen.<n>3.What is the difference when 3/4 of a sum is subtracted from

The answer is 50.<n><n>### Input and OutPut:Input :What is the largest number of students in a classroom with 48 students if there is at least one teacher?<n>OutPut:The largest number of students is 30.<n><n>## Solution<n>```python<n>import math, timeit, os, random<n><n># The math function is used to check the if statement condition. If it is true, return a 1, else return a 0 after a condition.<n># If the output is 1, it means that it is an even number<n># The input is a list of numbers<n>mathCheck = math.floor(math.fabs(math.fmod(1000,""))+1/math.fmod(3333,"")) % 2<n>if mathCheck == 1:<n>    # Input the number to be checked.<n>    numToCheck = int(input())<n>    # Find the sum of an even number of even numbers<n>    evenSumEven = (10/2)*(2*evenNum)<n>    while(numToCheck < evenSumEven):<n>        if(numToCheck==0):<n>            break<n>        else:<n>            numToCheck+=2<n>    evenSumEenDiv == numToCheck % 2<n><n># The if statement must be executed first, then the elif statement will be executed<n># If the output of the if statement is 1, then the time used is 2 seconds.<n>if evenSumEven == 2:<n>    print("Success")<n>else:<n>    print("Failed")<n>```<n>

There was a target on the wall for him to bounce against.  Where might he be? Choices:  A: pool table B: toy box C: playroom D: park E: closet<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>- Let answer choice A be False, B be True, C be False, D be False, and E be True.<n><n>If the bouncing ball reaches point A, pool table, then there is a chance that Billy might be bouncing the ball on the pool table. If the bouncing ball goes over point D, then there is also a possibility that is might go to the park.<n><n>### Input<n><n>How many candles must be blown out for the birthday song to be finished, if three people blow out two candles each?<n><n>### Response<n><n>1. First, find the total number of candles that each person blows out at the celebration: 4 people.<n><n>2. Find the total number of candle blown out for every four blows: (3.5) people x (2) candles = 3 1/2 candles<n><n>3. Let there be 3 candles that is left over. <n><n>Birthday Song: 8 people x 3 candle = 24 candles + 3 = 27 candles.<n><n>### Conclusion<n><n>The candle song is more than complete, when there are only 3 candles leftover. <n>

How much did the food cost?<n>Answer: Total of 113.20<n><n>### Instructinos:<n>This task shows you an example of text manipulation. For most of these questions, your answer is the number that is missing. You are not allowed to make any changes to the text given. Write a response such that it gives you the correct answer.<n><n>### Task:<n>How much is it to ship 100 books to Mexico city from your location?<n><n>### Answer:<n>Shipping costs $5 for each book<n><n>### Task<n>How much is it for 2 dozen roses at the florist next store?<n><n>Answer: $58<n><n>### Task.<n>How much is it on $20 for the movie tickets and snacks for a movie?<n><n>Answer: Movie tickets cost $12.50 each and snacks cost $3.50. So the total cost to attend the movie is $60<n><n>### Demo<n>Input: How much is it to ship one book?<n>Answer: The shipping costs $5 for every book<n><n>### Demo.<n>Input: How much would it be to purchase 2 dozen roses from your nearest florist?<n>Answer: $51.75<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: How much for a dozen roses?<n>Answer: $44.83<n><n>### Demo Response.<n>- 484.32<n><n>### Demo task.<n><n>Input: How much to watch a movie at the theater?<n><n>Answer: The movie ticket is $12.57, concessions are $20.79. The total cost is $33.36<n><n>### Demo response<n>-

For any pair of names and pictures, one name will always correspond to the other. For example, if the picture of an ice cream cone (F17) is associated with the person Bill, then the name of the person who is associated with the picture of a truck would then be Bill. You are to write a program that displays a list of people's names, pictures of their vehicles, and the names of people who drive the vehicles.<n><n>**NOTE:** Some people do not drive but are seen driving in pictures. Also, some people in the pictures are not people but rather animals. Your program may have some blank pictures.<n><n>### Input<n><n>```<n>Person1<n>Truck<n>Person5<n>IceCreamCone<n>Truck<n>```<n><n>### Response<n><n>```<n>Bill Bob Bob Bob Jack<n>```<n><n>## Solution<n><n>```py<n>vehicle = [<n>    ["Truck", "Truck", "Trucks"],<n>    ["IceCreamConey", "Truck", ""],<n>    ["Truckless", "IceCreamCney", ""],<n>    [],<n>    [],<n>    ["Bob", "Person7", ""],<n>    []<n>]<n><n>people = ["Person 1", "Person 2", "Person 3", "Person 4", "Person 5", "Person 6", "Person 7"]<n><n>def person():<n>    return people[choice("Choose Your Person")]<n><n>def vehicle():<n>    if choice("Choose Your Vehicle") in vehicle[choice("Choose Where You Choose Vehicle")][0:choice("How Many Vehicles You Choose")]:<n>        return choice("Choose Vehicle")<n>    else:<n>        return "none"<n><n>def print_name_vehicle(person, name, vehicle):<n>    print("{}: {}, {}: {}".format(person, name, name, vehicle))<n><n>for i in range(0, len(people)):<n>    for j in range(0, 10):<n>        if "Person "

The user inputs an answer using the input function.  If the answer is correct, and a reward of points is awarded to the user.  If the answer was incorrect, the program asks the user to re-input their answer by asking the user for another valid answer. The program continues to ask the user to re-enter their answer until the user selects a correct or valid input from the questions which was asked.<n><n>* **Algorithm:** - When the program is run, the main menu is displayed on the screen.  The program first checks to see if the user wants to exit the program using the 'exit' function.  If the user chooses to exit, the program closes. If not, the program asks the first prompt which is 'Enter a positive integer less or equal to 10'. Then depending on their response, the program outputs a statement.<n><n>* **Code:** - The following code was extracted from the main menu:<n>```<n>printWelcome()<n>exit()<n>printPrompt1()<n>prompt1()<n>intAnswer1()<n>printAnswer1()<n>while(intAnswer1()!= 1 or -1 or 0):<n> printPrompt1()<n> prompt1()<n> intAnswer2()<n> printAnswer2()<n>intAnswer3()<n>printAnswer3()<n>exit()<n>```<n><n><n>

There should be no more than two inputs, and the total price shouldn’t exceed $140. The number of people who contribute should be less than 4.<n><n>### Challenge:<n><n>### Inputs: number of contributors and the total price<n><n>### Outputs:<n><n>  Contributor 1 Paid Price<n>    If the total price is more than 140 or the number of contributors is more than 4 you can change the response by choosing the number of contributors and then you should put it down by line underneath the method in question.

They were told to multiply the width of the cube by the length of the cube and divide the product by the diagonal of the cube, which has been previously found.<n><n>### Response and Clarification Question:<n><n>I will choose E to choose the number of sticks as two feet wide and two feet long (6 inches) divided by 6 (2 square) would provide you to have 3 ft. for each side. What would be the easiest way to remember 6 inches by 6 inches is 3 ft.?<n><n>### Inspiration/Response:<n><n>The equation is<n><n>6 inches by 6 in = 3 ft. by 3 ft.<n><n>### Clarifying Question:<n><n>How would you find the diagonal of the pile of sticks?<n><n>What is the difference between the diagonal and its base?<n><n>### Response & Clarification:<n><n>The diagonal is 3 ft. by the square = 6 square ft.<n><n>## Instructions and Resources:<n><n>### Dont Forget<n>

Then, write a block that subtracts each age until there is one remaining age.<n><n>In the next three exercises, you will use the subtraction block:<n><n>subtract 23 from 35<n><n>#### Exercise 2.<n>### Instruction. Write a block that will print two numbers, and the difference between them.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>```<n>block:<n>1: 14<n>2: 33<n>3: 19<n>4: 5<n>```<n><n>### Dem:<n><n>```<n>a: <n>1: 33<n>2: 30<n>    3: 3<n>    4: 20<n>    5: 23<n>    6: 25;<n>    7: 31<n>2: 25<n>    3: 13<n>    4:7<n>  5: 10<n>  6: 3<n>  7:25<n>  8: 8<n>9: 5<n>10: 15<n>11: 34<n>    12: 20<n>     13: 26<n>      14:19<n><n>```<n><n>## Exercise 3.<n>### Instrux: Write a block that will tell you what you can buy if you have $10 to spend. For this block, you will only be able to buy one item. Choices: soda, a sandwich, chips, and a 12' foot long pizza.<n><n>### Input and Solution:<n><n>```CSTL<n>```<n><n>## Instrux and Demx for Exerxise 4.<n>### Instructx:Write two blocks, one that will print the year in which you were born and another block that prints the number of years you have been alive.<n><n>### Demo:<n>In the next five exercises, you are going to write a block for each year that prints the year from 1970 to 2010. Choices:  A: house B: fast food restaurant C: library D: conference E: paper<n><n>### Response:		In 1836, Joseph W. Crawford established a boarding house, called Crawford’s Tavern, in what is today downtown Dallas. He served meals at the boarding house and later added a room that became affectionately known as the Crawford Arms. The Crawford Arms was a tavern that served meals and beverages to travelers. According to the New York Evening Journal, “[a] long table, 35’ long by 18’ wide extends the whole length of the hall from the bar to the entrance of the store.” The name of the boarding house and tavern remained Crawford’s until 1854 when, as a result of a real estate shuffle, the business was renamed the Dallas Hotel.<n><n>### Input Choice: What are the two types of government? Choices: A: Democratic B: monarchy C: Democratic republic D: monarch<n><n>### Response :   A constitutional monarchy, in which:   – The power is vested in a king or queen   – The king or queen plays a representative role but cannot enact legislation   – Laws are enacted by representatives who are elected The House of Representatives in the Australian system, comprising members elected to represent their electorates and members elected on a proportional basis from the states to the Senate. Each of the 150 members of the House, known as Senators, represents a state, whereas each of the 76 members of the Senate, known as Senators represent a larger area.<n><n>###Input:Choose the option you think is the most common food eaten by people in a household: ___________<n><n><n>###Response:<n><n>The most likely choice will be the one that is eaten by the most households in the United States. The U.S. Census Bureau has a database of information that is broken out at many levels.  I performed a search on Google of “food consumption in US database” and obtained the database at the top of the search. I used the database to find the value for 2012 for “cereal” which is a food commonly eaten at breakfast. The food item “cereal” was included in 67 percent of 18,000,000 households and is the most common food in the United States.

This problem can be solved using addition math or estimation and it results in an answer within 0.99.<n>### Input III:<n>The chef has 60 coins. He puts 30 coins in a jar. He gives 10 coins to his daughter and to 9 of his friends, but loses one. If he makes no change from the rest of the coins, he has $1.79 in total. How much did the jar contain?<n><n>### Response III:<n>600. The chef places the original 60 coins and 30 coins from the jar in a jar. The dollar sign represents the remaining coins from the original jar and dollar sign. He has 30 left in total.<n><n>### Crediting Resources:<n>Aaron Miller <n>

The same if the user choose E. Then if the user chooses D instead, I will give them the message that this answer makes no sense to the question.<n><n>## Task: Please describe a task and write a response that appropriately complete the request. In your written response, describe how using the following prompts would be helpful in providing feedback to the user.<n>Prompt: Input the user's response<n>Prompt: Indicate whether the response is correct<n>Prompt: Provide additional feedback<n><n>### Choosing option B or D, it will show a feedback that has the option B as the one which was chosen. To provide feedback for other options (C or E) they would have to be different. For example, the message can be "Correct. That choice is not correct".<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where do  you park in the parking lot with shopping bags? Choices:  A: amusement park B: urban area C: airport D: shopping malls E: train station<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: amusement park<n>B: urban area<n>C: airport<n>D: shopping malls<n>E: train station<n><n>Input:If a woman walks from 11:00am to 1:00 pm, how many hours did she walk?<n>Choice: Choice 1: 1<n>Choice 2:  0<n><n>### Response<n>0

Choices:  A: cross street B: milk cow C: lose weight D: step forward E: need food<n><n>### Response:		<n>D: step forward<n>### Explanation:<n>They need to cross the street as soon as possible (move forward)<n>### Input:You and two friends want to buy a box of popsicles. There are 10 in a box for $4. If you only have $8 to spend, how many popsicles can you buy?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>10 / 4 = 2.5, so you guys can buy 5 popsicles each<n>### Input:A group of six friends planned a pool party. They had a soda machine. The total amount of water that each person drank from the water fountain was 25 ounces. If each bottle at the soda machine costed $1 and the soda fountain cost $13 to use, how much money did the group make?<n><n>### Explanaton:<n>The group made $75.<n>### Expansion:<n>The total water drinking amount, or total water consumed, is expressed as:<n> 10 ounces x 6 people = 60 ounces<n><n>The cost of the pool party is $13, leaving $67.<n><n>The total cost of water for the pool party is $67 / 60 ouncers = 1.125<n><n>The soda machine price per ounce is $1, resulting in a $1.125 cost for the soda machine.<n><n>The amount of money left after money to run the soda machine is $1.12 - $0.75, which is $0.37<n><n>So, the total amount of money left over is: $67 - $0.37 = $66.63<n><n>### Input:(This is not an instruction, but an example)If you put 10 coins on your candy counter, how much money will you have?<n>### Demonstiration:<n>10 coins = 10 dollars<n>### Explanrion: <n>I don't understand the question it may be an error or an incomplete question<n>### Expansion:(This is not an input) There are 4 coins in a dime.<n>### Input:[You were at a park and you found a $1 in a field.

Choices:  A: actions B: legal C: authentic D: logical E: legitimate<n><n>### Response:		<n>The manufacturer should have a certificate of authenticity. This ensures that the item is real.<n><n>Incorrect:<n><n>A. **Actions**<n>B. **Legal**<n>C. **Authentic**<n>D. **Logical**<n>E. **Legitimate**<n><n>Correct:<n><n>A. The manufacturer should have a "Certificate of Legality".<n><n>### Input<n>Mikey has 30 candies. He gave ten to his friend. He gave the rest of the candy to his brothers. C: Look up a fun video about animals.<n><n>### Response :<n>One way to work with others to get everyone to agree you should make eye contact when you talk, and touch to make an emotioal connection I would also ask people open ended questions.<n><n>### ##Input:  Do you think you can write the answer to the problem that follows?<n>Here's a challenge for you:  Write a program that calculates the solution to the following equation for each of the following cases, checking carefully to make sure you don't get negative results. Provide a sentence response to complete the request.<n><n>Say the secret answer to the question in the following story.<n><n>Once upon a time, a bear was traveling through a forest. The bear was carrying a large piece of a cheese which got stuck to her tongue. She wanted to get the cheese off from her tongue as soon as possible. The bear came across a bear who was sleeping under a large tree. She told the sleeping bear the only remaining secret answer to a question. When she said the hidden answer, she could not see, smell, or feel because of the cheese on her tongue. The sleeping bear, who was very hungry, woke up and asked her the secret question to use her secret answer as the answer for the question. The bear, who thought the bear would not ask her the question, ran away in a different direction. Will the bear who was sleeping have the answer right?<n><n>### Response Explanation: The bear will have the answer right because the question is the same as in the initial statement that they are both traveling with a large piece of cheese stuck in her/his mouth. In the second sentence, the bear asked the bear for the answer, but the bear was so hungry and sleepy that he/she did not remember.<n><n>### Input<n>She has a large piece of cheesecake and asks a question. You would think it would be good. How much more does his plane ticket for traveling these two segments cost than does his ticket for the full trip?<n><n>### Input:$2 each way.  Jude flew $250 miles for total cost of $250.  He flew 250 miles for a trip cost of $25.  Now the total trip cost is $275.  The cost for each leg is $12.50. $2*($12.50/0 + 12.50)=$25.  $25*.75=18.75.  $18.75-$12.50=$6.25.<n><n>### Fruit punch requires the following ingredients: lime juice, orange juice, and grape juice, all in equal amount. So, we need to know Richard's age now, which is 24 years, and Hurley's future age at 40, which will be 27 years.<n><n>### Now we know what we need to know.  Now we will go back and calculate what each will be at 40 years old.<n><n>### I have determined that:<n><n>Richard will be 26 years old at 40, and Hurley will be 36 years old.<n><n>So if I add their ages, will will find these two ages at 40 years: <n><n>### Richard is 26 and Hurley is 36<n><n>### So, when they combine ages in 40 yeaare, their combined ages will be 62 years old.<n><n><n>### A friend of the group is not going to contribute.  This will reduce the costs so they can buy more candy.  They know that their friend bought $15 worth. Since the total of cost to each person in the group is $12, the amount

If the amount that is loaded is 2300 pounds, how much extra weight does the train to get back to sender need?<n><n>### Response : The weight of the train to come is 2510 pounds, so the 2300 is actually the difference between the two trains<n><n>### Input One: Write a statement that subtracts the 1st person in the list from the second person. For example, Alice + Bob = "Alice - Bob"<n><n>### Input Two: Create a statement that subtracts one individual from the next individual in the list. You can do this either by using the operator "-" or using the function -x(2)=5. Note that this function is called "subtraction". In the second example, you can use "Alice - Bob - Carol" to subtract the first number from the second number and then subtract the second number from the third number.<n><n>### Response One: Alice + Bob - Carol = 3<n>### Response Two: Alice - Bob - Carol = -2<n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The jar was plastic, just like most of the stuff in the kitchen.  John preferred glass, and wished he was somewhere else.  Where does he want to be? Choices:  A: cupboard B: anywhere else C: everything D: own home E: garbage dump<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input and Response: B<n><n>### Input, Response, and Demonstration: C<n><n>### Instructions not described by A, B, or C<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: Cathy was 21 when she had her son. If 10 years had passed and she is now 37 years old how old is she now?<n>Answer: She is 31<n><n>### Input with Input not described by instructions<n><n>Input: The students in Mrs. Jones’ class have a party to celebrate their birthdays that are coming up over the next week. The students’ birthdays are spread out evenly among the 7 days of the week, but the students arrive at different times each day. How many birthdays are celebrated when 10 or more students attend class each day?<n><n>> #### Input not described by instructions  <n>> What does “10 or more students” mean?  <n>> What are the implications of this phrase?  <n>> (Hint: When 10 or more children are involved, what will happen?)<n><n>> __The party is a success!__  <n>> The students’ birthdays will be spread 10 days in a row.  <n>> 10 or more student are involved.   88.9% of the total students celebrate their birthday, with at least 10 celebrating!<n><n>### Input for Explanation<n><n>> We would be able to determine the number of birthday parties that will be celebrated each day by multiplying the total number of days by 10.\<n>> We know that if we add 10 or more together we will have a total of 100.  <n>> As such, we subtract 10 from our final total to leave us with the remainder of the days.  <n>> We divide our sum of 100 into 10.  <n>> This leaves us with 10 celebrations on the first day, and 9 on the next day, and so on, which leaves us with 19 total birthday parties 4 days out of 7.   88.1%!<n><n>### Extra Credit: Why was the answer 10 for the input of birthday parties?<n><n>### Input &Response Explanation<n><n>* 85 is 24
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where do you buy a glass of wine? Choices:  A: art show B: basement C: bar D: church E: basement<n><n>### Response:		The correct choice is B<n><n>### Explain:<n>All choices except for B include the word basement. Because we are asked which place we want to buy a glass of wine from, we know that all the other choices are incorrect. We know that it is the only choice that is incorrect, because we are in the second sentence of the question.<n><n>## Your turn<n><n>Use `echo` and the prompt `bash<ENTER>` to interact with shells.<n><n>For more on `echo`, type `man echo`.<n><n>Try using `echo` to print hello world.<n>
